ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned a great deal about racial capitalism and the carceral state.  Beginning with the origins of the concept of race, chattel slavery, and the current model of incarceration then going to Reconstruction and the race and the formation of the ghetto at the turn of the 20th Century, and finally ending with the creation of the current carceral state.  I learned how all of these institutions were formed and interact with one another, as well as how they interact with other power hierarchies like heteronormativity, the gender binary, and class society.

I gained a critical understanding of limitations of liberalism. I also gained an understanding of how systems of subordination are harnessed and (re)produced across space and time, specifically analyzing the the ways that slavery, ghettoization, and the prison industrial complex have rest on and reify racial typographies and unequal relations of power.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The readings for this class were phenomenal, and the lecturer did an astounding job giving context during class.  I feel like we really touched on everything needed to fully understand the current material conditions in the US.  My only gripe was that we didn't have much time to delve more into community-based solutions to the problems we discussed like mutual aid.

The course readings and quasi-lecture format at the beginning of the seminar were very enriching. The professor was also very charismatic and created an affirmative community that facilitated learning. I also enjoyed the inclusion of a guest lecturer on abolitionism.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Most definitely!  Whether they are just learning about the carceral state and race in the US, or if they're a major theory nerd who runs 15 book clubs and can quote Marcuse backwards, I think that anybody (but especially social science majors) will get a lot out of this class.  This is exactly the class anybody who wants to better understand inequality and exploitation in the US needs to take.

Yes, I would recommend this course to another student. The course readings and quasi-lecture format at the beginning of the seminar were very enriching. The professor was also very charismatic and created an affirmative community that facilitated learning. I also enjoyed the inclusion of a guest lecturer on abolitionism.  I gained a critical understanding of limitations of liberalism. I also gained an understanding of how systems of subordination are harnessed and (re)produced across space and time, specifically analyzing the the ways that slavery, ghettoization, and the prison industrial complex have rest on and reify racial typographies and unequal relations of power.

narratives.question_text: The Canvas course site allowed me to identify and access required course materials easily.
How will you use the knowledge and skills you learned in this course in your future endeavors?
comments: Before this class, I already partially understood the concept of prison abolition and wanted to learn more.  This class has given me a strong enough grasp on the theory that I feel comfortable calling myself an abolitionist ready to engage in the praxis needed to make those ideas a reality.  I am also much more able to engage in discourse surrounding racial capitalism as well and I believe that I will be a better advocate/organizer for it.

I will use the critical frameworks that I gained from this course to evaluate and assess laws, policies, and even reforms that are enacted under the aegis of progressivism and individual freedom in order to determine whether these policies reinforce, reproduce, or legitimize unequal relations of power or maintain systems of subordination. I will also use this knowledge to guide and inform my social justice commitments, including abolitionism, mutual aid, and public interest law.
